patterns.title: E&M Visits Missing Modifier 25
patterns.description: Evaluation and Management (E&M) visits performed on the same day as a procedure are being denied due to missing modifier 25, which indicates a separately identifiable E&M service.
patterns.suggestedAction: Always add modifier 25 to E&M codes (99213-99215) when performed with same-day procedures. Use the Claim Lab to practice identifying these scenarios.

signals: Same error across multiple coders
Pattern spans different E&M code levels
possibleRootCauses.explanation: Billing system may not prompt for modifier 25 when E&M is billed with same-day procedures.

signals: Pattern isolated to specific procedure combinations
possibleRootCauses.explanation: Coders may not recognize when E&M service is separately identifiable from the procedure.

shortTermAction.description: Add modifier 25 to E&M codes on affected claims and resubmit.

longTermAction.description: Configure billing system to prompt for modifier 25 evaluation when E&M is billed with same-day procedures.
steps: Review billing system edit configuration for E&M + procedure combinations
Add pre-submission prompt or auto-flag for modifier 25 review
Brief coding staff on modifier 25 requirements for separately identifiable services
Monitor denial rate for this pattern over next 30 days

patterns.title: High-Value Procedures Without Prior Authorization
patterns.description: Colonoscopies, joint injections, and other high-value procedures are being denied because prior authorization was not obtained before the service.
patterns.suggestedAction: Implement a pre-service authorization checklist for all procedures with codes 45378, 20610, and other high-value services. Verify auth status before scheduling.

signals: Scheduling staff not checking auth requirements
Auth status not visible in scheduling workflow
possibleRootCauses.explanation: Scheduling staff not checking auth requirements before booking procedures.

signals: Different payers have different auth requirements
Auth lists not centrally maintained
possibleRootCauses.explanation: Auth requirements vary by payer and are not centrally tracked.

shortTermAction.description: These claims cannot be resubmitted as prior authorization cannot be obtained retroactively for most payers. Focus on prevention.

longTermAction.description: Implement pre-scheduling auth verification workflow to prevent future authorization denials.
steps: Create payer-specific auth requirement matrix for common procedures
Add auth verification step to scheduling workflow
Train scheduling staff on checking auth status before booking
Set up automated auth status alerts for pending procedures

patterns.title: Insufficient Documentation for Medical Necessity
patterns.description: Claims are being denied due to insufficient documentation to support the medical necessity of the service provided.
patterns.suggestedAction: Ensure all claims include detailed clinical notes, diagnosis rationale, and treatment plan. Use documentation templates to capture required elements.

signals: Clinical notes lack medical necessity language
Missing diagnosis rationale in documentation
possibleRootCauses.explanation: Clinical notes lack specific medical necessity language required by payers.

signals: Documentation completed at end of day
Templates missing required fields
possibleRootCauses.explanation: Providers rushing documentation at end of day, missing key elements.

shortTermAction.description: Resubmit denied claims with addended documentation including medical necessity rationale.

longTermAction.description: Implement documentation templates with required medical necessity elements.
steps: Create documentation templates with required medical necessity fields
Train providers on documentation requirements for common services
Add real-time documentation completeness checks in EHR
Implement pre-submission review for high-value claims

patterns.title: Incorrect Procedure Code Bundling
patterns.description: Procedures that should be bundled under a single code are being billed separately, resulting in denials for unbundling violations.
patterns.suggestedAction: Review CCI edits before billing. Use coding software to identify bundled procedures. Focus on common bundles like venipuncture with office visits.

signals: Coders billing separately for bundled services
CCI edits not referenced before submission
possibleRootCauses.explanation: Coders not referencing CCI edits before submission, resulting in unbundling violations.

signals: No pre-submission bundling checks
Software lacks CCI edit integration
possibleRootCauses.explanation: Billing software lacks built-in CCI edit checking to flag bundling issues.

shortTermAction.description: Bundling violations cannot be resubmitted. These represent lost revenue. Focus on prevention through improved pre-submission checks.

longTermAction.description: Integrate CCI edit checking into claim scrubbing workflow to catch bundling issues before submission.
steps: Integrate CCI edit database into billing software
Add pre-submission bundling violation alerts
Monthly coding team review of common bundling scenarios
Create quick-reference guide for high-frequency bundle combinations

patterns.title: Claims Submitted Outside Timely Filing Window
patterns.description: Claims are being denied because they were submitted beyond the payer's timely filing limit, typically 90-120 days from date of service.
patterns.suggestedAction: Implement automated claim submission alerts. Review all claims older than 60 days weekly. Set up aging reports in practice management system.

signals: No aging alerts configured
Claims stuck in pending without review
possibleRootCauses.explanation: No automated alerts for claims approaching filing deadline.

signals: Claims in pending/hold status not monitored
Manual submission process
possibleRootCauses.explanation: Claims stuck in pending status not being monitored regularly.

shortTermAction.description: Timely filing denials cannot be appealed. This revenue is lost. Focus entirely on prevention.

longTermAction.description: Implement automated claim aging alerts to prevent future timely filing denials.
steps: Configure automated alerts at 60/75/85 days from service date
Establish weekly claims aging report review process
Create escalation workflow for claims approaching deadline
Track and report on near-miss claims monthly

patterns.title: Non-Covered Services Billed to Primary Payer
patterns.description: Services not covered by the patient's insurance plan are being submitted to the primary payer instead of being billed directly to patient or secondary insurance.
patterns.suggestedAction: Verify insurance coverage before service. Obtain advance beneficiary notices (ABNs) for non-covered services. Update patient responsibility estimates.

signals: Coverage not verified before service
Plan limitations unknown at time of service
possibleRootCauses.explanation: Coverage limitations not verified before service.

signals: No ABN process in place
Front desk not trained on ABN requirements
possibleRootCauses.explanation: Front desk not obtaining ABNs for potentially non-covered services.

shortTermAction.description: Bill patient or secondary insurance for non-covered amounts where ABN was obtained.

longTermAction.description: Implement pre-visit eligibility and benefits verification to identify coverage gaps.
steps: Add eligibility verification to scheduling workflow
Train front desk on ABN requirements and process
Create coverage alert system for common non-covered services
Update patient financial responsibility estimates pre-visit

patterns.title: Missing or Incorrect Diagnosis Code Specificity
patterns.description: Claims are being denied because diagnosis codes lack required specificity (e.g., using unspecified codes when more specific codes exist).
patterns.suggestedAction: Use the most specific ICD-10 code available. Avoid .9 unspecified codes when laterality or additional detail is known. Review diagnosis code guidelines quarterly.

signals: High use of .9 unspecified codes
Coders selecting first match instead of most specific
possibleRootCauses.explanation: Coders defaulting to unspecified codes for speed.

signals: Clinical notes missing laterality
Diagnosis type not specified in documentation
possibleRootCauses.explanation: Clinical documentation not specifying laterality or type needed for specific codes.

shortTermAction.description: Resubmit with corrected specific diagnosis codes based on clinical documentation.

longTermAction.description: Add coding software alerts for unspecified codes and train providers on documentation specificity.
steps: Configure alerts for .9 and other unspecified code submissions
Train coders on selecting most specific diagnosis codes
Educate providers on documenting laterality and type
Implement quarterly diagnosis coding audits
